case_name: Bijay Cotton Mills Ltd. v. their workmen

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 355 of 1958 is an appeal by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 355 of 1958.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the decision dated December 12, 1956 of the Labour Appellate Tribunal of India, Bombay in Appeals Nos. 77 and 103 of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the decision dated December 12, 1956, of the Labour Appellate Tribunal of India, Bombay in Appeal Bom. Nos. 77and 103 of 1956.

facts.text: Judgment of the Court delivered by GAJENDRAGADKAR, J. on February 12, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: 1960. February, 12. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by GAJENDRAGADKAR, J.-

facts.text: Industrial dispute between Bijay Cotton Mills Ltd. (appellant) and their workmen (respondents).

anchor.surface_text: The industrial dispute between the Bijay Cotton Mills Ltd., hereinafter called the appellant and their workmen hereinafter called the respondents which has given rise to this appeal by special leave has gone through a protracted and tortuous companysse.

facts.text: Respondents claimed that scale of minimum wages and rates for contract works should be fixed as payments by appellant were below bare subsistence wage.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents claimed that the scale of minimum wages and rates for companytract works should be fixed for them because it was alleged that the payments made by the appellant were below the level of the bare subsistence wage.

facts.text: Appellant did not accede to the demand made by respondents.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant did number accede to the demand thus made by the respondents,

facts.text: Present dispute referred for adjudication on December 1, 1950 to Industrial Tribunal consisting of Mr. D. N. Roy under s.10(1) read with s.12(5) of Industrial Disputes Act, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: and so on December 1, 1950, the-present dispute was referred for adjudication to the Industrial Tribunal companysisting of Mr. D. N. Roy, under s. 10 1  read with s. 12 5  of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947  Act XIV of 1947   hereinafter called the Act .

facts.text: Items referred included minimum wages and rates for contract works as per statements and dearness allowance at Rs. 35 per mensem varying with prices.

anchor.surface_text: Amongst the items thus referred for adjudication, the first two were  1  that the mill employees be paid minimum wages and rates for companytract works as shown in the two statements enclosed, and  2  that dearness allowance be paid to all workers at the rate of. Rs. 35 permensem each and it may be increased or decreased according to rise or fall in prices.

facts.text: Mr. Roy announced award on October 5, 1951 without fixing basic minimum wage citing difficulties due to industrial development in Ajmer and price fluctuations.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that Mr. Roy found himself unable to fix any basic minimum wage, and to support his view, that it would be inexpedient to fix any minimum basic wage in the proceedings pending before him, he referred to the fact that the question of fixation of the basic wage had been rendered enormously difficult by the state of industrial development in the State of Ajmer and by the unsteady and frequent fluctuations in prices. Even so be companysidered several items of dispute referred to him and announced his award on October 5, 1951.

facts.text: Roy's award challenged by respondents before Labour Appellate Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: This award was challenged by the respondents before the Labour Appellate Tribunal.

facts.text: Labour Appellate Tribunal remanded matter to Mr. Roy on October 20, 1952 directing specific determination of basic wage and dearness allowance.

anchor.surface_text: The appellate tribunal there upon remanded the matter to Mr. Roy with a direction that the issues as to the basic wage and as to dearness allowance should be specifically determined and appropriate directions issued on those two items. This remand order was passed on October 20, 1952.

facts.text: Mr. Roy unavailable on remand as he ceased to be District Judge in Ajmer; Mr. Sharma appointed instead.

anchor.surface_text: By the time the proceedings were taken up before the tribunal on remand, Mr. Roy was number available because he had ceased to be a District Judge in Ajmer. In his place Mr. Sharma was appointed.

facts.text: Mr. Sharma made award on September 8, 1953 fixing Rs. 25 basic wage and Rs. 10 minimum dearness allowance.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Sharma then made his award on September 8, 1953. He fixed Rs. 25 as basic wage and Rs. 10 as minimum dearness allowance.

facts.text: Sharma's award quashed on May 25, 1955 as appointment not duly published under the Act.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that the award thus made by Mr. Sharma was subsequently quashed on the ground that his appointment had number been duly published as required by the Act. This order was passed on May 25, 1955.

facts.text: Mr. C. Jacob appointed Industrial Tribunal and made award on January 25, 1956 fixing Rs. 25 basic wage and Rs. 10 minimum dearness allowance operative from December 1, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. C. Jacob was then appointed Industrial Tribunal. He made his award on January 25, 1956. By this award Mr. Jacob in substance agreed with the view taken by Mr. Sharma and fixed the basic wage at Rs. 25 per mensem and the minimum dearness allowance at Rs. 10 per mensem. This award was directed to companye into operation as from December 1, 1950.

facts.text: Jacob's award challenged before Labour Appellate Tribunal which partly allowed respondents' appeal increasing basic wage to Rs. 30 per mensem while affirming Rs. 10 dearness allowance on December 12, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: This award was again challenged before the Labour Appellate Tribunal and the appellate tribunal has partly allowed the appeal preferred by the respondents and increased the basic wage from Rs. 25 per mensem to Rs. 30 per mensem. The amount of the minimum dearness allowance has been affirmed at Rs. 10 permensem. This decision was announced by the appellate tribunal on December 12, 1956.

facts.text: Statutory Committee appointed under Minimum Wages Act, 1948 for Ajmer on January 17, 1952; report October 4, 1952; notification October 7, 1952 effective January 8, 1953 fixing basic minimum wage Rs. 30 and dearness allowance Rs. 26 per mensem.

anchor.surface_text: It is companymon ground that a Statutory Committee was appointed under Minimum Wages Act, 1948  Act XI of 1948  in respect of Ajmer on January 17, 1952. Its report was submitted on October 4, 1952, and a numberification was issued in pursuance of the said report on October 7, 1952. This numberification has companye into force as from January 8, 1953, and in companysequence the basic minimum wage is number statutorily fixed at Rs. 30 per mensem and dearness allowance at Rs. 26 per mensem.

facts.text: No dispute between parties on basic wage and minimum dearness allowance after January 8, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: Thus it would be clear that there is numberdispute between the parties as to what would be the basic wage and the minimum dearness allowance subsequent to January 8, 1953.

facts.text: Agreement between parties in December 1949 under which respondents were willing to work on minimum wage of Rs. 27.

anchor.surface_text: The other fact on which reliance was placed was that there was an agreement between the parties in December 1949, under which the respondents were willing to work on the minimum wage of Rs. 27.

facts.text: Appellant and respondents jointly challenged Ajmer Government notification fixing basic wage at Rs. 30 from January 8, 1953 in Bijay Cotton Mills Ltd. v. State of Ajmer; Supreme Court upheld validity of Minimum Wages Act and notification.

anchor.surface_text: In fact it appears that both the appellant and the respondents had moved this Court for striking down the numberification issued by the Ajmer Government by which the basic wage had been fixed at Rs. 30 from January 8, 1953. In Bijay Cotton Mills Ltd. v. The State of Ajmer  1  it was urged on their behalf jointly that the relevant provisions of the Minimum Wages Act were ultra vires and that it would be in the interests of the employer and the employees as well to strike down the impugned numberification. This Court rejected the said companytention and upheld the validity of the Act as well as of the numberification.

facts.text: Appellant started textile business in 1940.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant started its textile business in 940

facts.text: Appellant faced serious calamity in 1943 resulting in great loss and liability of nearly thirty lakhs rupees.

anchor.surface_text: and had to face a serious calamity in 1943, as a result of which it suffered great loss and incurred liability to the tune of nearly rupees thirty lakhs.

facts.text: Large section of respondents belonged to agricultural class and could supplement income from agricultural sources.

anchor.surface_text: Besides, it was urged before the tribunal that a large section of the respondents belonged to the agricultural class and they can supplement their income from agricultural sources.

facts.text: Mr. Sharma's appointment as Industrial Tribunal made on December 31, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: The argument is that Mr. Sharmas appointment as Industrial Tribunal made on December 31, 1954, was subsisting at the time when Mr. Jacob was appointed on June 17, 1955,

facts.text: Mr. Jacob appointed on June 17, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: was subsisting at the time when Mr. Jacob was appointed on June 17, 1955,

facts.text: Mr. Sharma's earlier appointment made on May 4, 1953 not duly published or notified as required by the Act.

anchor.surface_text: his earlier appointment made on May 4, 1953, had number been duly published and numberified as required by the Act.

facts.text: At time proceedings after remand commenced, Mr. Sharma's services not available as not in service of the State.

anchor.surface_text: at the time when the proceedings after the remand companymenced Mr. Sharmas services were number available, as he was apparently number in the service of the State,

which should be corrected by us in our jurisdiction under Art. 136 of the Constitution. Therefore, we are not satisfied that any case for interference has been made out by the appellant on this point.

concepts.unlisted_description: Standard for Supreme Court interference in Art.136 appeals

issues.text: Whether there is any case for interference under Article 136 of the Constitution with the Labour Appellate Tribunal's increase of the basic minimum wage from Rs. 25 to Rs. 30 per mensem by relying on the statutory notification under the Minimum Wages Act instead of the industry-cum-region basis adopted by the Industrial Tribunal

anchor.surface_text: It is this modification that is challenged before us by Mr. A. V. Viswanatha Sastri on behalf of the appellant. Mr. Sastri contends that the method adopted by the tribunal was a scientific method it took into account a basic wage deducible on the industry-cum-region basis and this should not have been reversed by the appellate tribunal. It, however, appears that in ascertaining the wages which labour in comparable trades was getting in the relevant region, the tribunal has completely lost sight of the fact that in addition to the basic wages of Rs. 26/- Rs. 43/- was the average minimum dearness allowance paid to the workers and that made a very large difference in the total earnings of the workmen.

issues.text: Whether the appointment of Mr. Jacob as Industrial Tribunal was invalid on the ground that Mr. Sharma's appointment was subsisting and the dispute could not be referred to another tribunal

anchor.surface_text: The next contention raised by Mr. Sastri is that the appointment of Mr. Jacob who made his award on January 25, 1956, was invalid, and Mr. Sastri suggests that the said award as well as the decision of the appellate tribunal should be set aside and the matter should be sent back to Mr. Sharma for disposal in accordance with law. The argument is that Mr. Sharmas appointment as Industrial Tribunal made on December 31, 1954, was subsisting at the time when Mr. Jacob was appointed on June 17, 1955, and it is urged that when the same industrial dispute had already been referred to Mr. Sharma, it was not competent to the appropriate authority to refer the same dispute to Mr. Jacob.

issues.text: Whether the Chief Commissioner of Ajmer was competent to refer the dispute for adjudication under s. 10(1) read with s. 12(5) of the Industrial Disputes Act or whether only the Central Government was the appropriate government because the textile industry is a controlled industry under the Industrial (Development and Regulation) Act, 1951

anchor.surface_text: The last contention urged is that the reference is invalid inasmuch as the Chief Commissioner of Ajmer was not competent to refer the present dispute for adjudication under s. 10 1  read with s. 12 5  of the Act. The argument is that the Textile Industry has been included at serial No. 23 in the First Schedule to the Industrial  Development and Regulation  Act, 1951  Act 65 of 1951  and as such the Chief Commissioner of Ajmer was not the appropriate Government under s. 2 a  i  of the Act. It is urged that the present dispute could have been validly referred for adjudication to the industrial tribunal only by the Central Government.

arguments.claim: Appointment of Mr. Sharma's award quashed because not duly published, but later notification on Dec 31 1954 subsisting, so Mr. Jacob's appointment invalid; cannot refer same dispute to another tribunal; send back to Sharma.

anchor.surface_text: The next contention raised by Mr. Sastri is that the appointment of Mr. Jacob who made his award on January 25, 1956, was invalid, and Mr. Sastri suggests that the said award as well as the decision of the appellate tribunal should be set aside and the matter should be sent back to Mr. Sharma for disposal in accordance with law. The argument is that Mr. Sharmas appointment as Industrial Tribunal made on December 31, 1954, was subsisting at the time when Mr. Jacob was appointed on June 17, 1955, and it is urged that when the same industrial dispute had already been referred to Mr. Sharma, it was not competent to the appropriate authority to refer the same dispute to Mr. Jacob. In support of this argument reliance is placed on the decision of this Court in The State of Bihar v. D. N. Ganguly Ors.

arguments.claim: The Labour Appellate Tribunal erred in reversing Industrial Tribunal's scientific method of industry-cum-region basis for Rs. 25 basic wage; should not prefer Minimum Wages Act notification.

anchor.surface_text: It is this modification that is challenged before us by Mr. A. V. Viswanatha Sastri on behalf of the appellant. arguments.court_reasoning: Tribunal ignored dearness allowance in comparables making total earnings higher; no satisfactory evidence before tribunal; statutory notification best guide even prior; no error of law for Art 136 interference.

arguments.claim: In absence of satisfactory evidence, statutory notification under Minimum Wages Act best and safest guide for minimum wage fixation even prior to January 8 1953; increase to Rs 30.

anchor.surface_text: The Labour Appellate Tribunal, on the other hand, has held that, in the absence of satisfactory evidence on the record, the statutory notification issued under the Minimum Wages Act affords the best and safest guide in the matter of fixation of minimum wage . It has observed that even though the notification can have no application prior to January 8, 1953, still they were of opinion that the scales of wages fixed thereunder should not be departed from even for the period not in question.

arguments.court_reasoning: Useful material lacking; statutory committee considered relevant factors; preferable to unsatisfactory evidence; continuity with post-1953 statutory wage reasonable; no error of law.

arguments.claim: Basic wage Rs 25 on industry-cum-region basis: comparables in Rajasthan Rs 21-30, Beawar Rs 25; prior agreement Dec 1949 Rs 27; company calamity 1943 losses Rs 30 lakhs; workers agricultural supplement income.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that Mr. Jacob who fixed the basic minimum wage at Rs. 25 per mensem relied upon the fact that the said rate represented the basic minimum wage on the industry-cum- region basis. He has observed that the basic minimum wage of an unskilled worker in the textile mills in Bombay was Rs. 30 per mensem, while at other places it varies from Rs. 22 to Rs. 30 per mensem. Then he has also referred to the two charts, Exhibits 4-A and 4-B, produced by the respondents where the minimum basic wages were shown to range between Rs. 21 to Rs. 30 in Rajasthan.

holdings.text: we are not satisfied that any case for interference has been made out by the appellant on this point

anchor.surface_text: which should be corrected by us in our jurisdiction under Art. 136 of the Constitution. Therefore, we are number satisfied that any case for interference has been made out by the appellant on this point.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Industrial Tribunal's industry-cum-region method infirm as it ignored substantial dearness allowance in comparable wages; no satisfactory or useful evidence before tribunal; statutory Minimum Wages Act notification constitutes best and safest guide even for pre-notification period; award ensures wage continuity; no error of law warranting Art. 136 interference

holdings.text: there is no substance in the contention that the decision of Mr. Jacob is invalid in law

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, there is numbersubstance in the companytention that the decision of Mr. Jacob is invalid in law.

holdings.reasoning_summary: December 31, 1954 notification corrective for prior invalid non-published May 4, 1953 appointment; Mr. Sharma's services unavailable as not in State service when remand proceedings commenced; appropriate Government competent to appoint successor Mr. Jacob to fill vacancy

holdings.text: the Central Government must specify in this behalf that the industry in question is a controlled industry... no such specification has been made by the Central Government

anchor.surface_text: What this latter provision requires is that the Central Government must specify in this behalf that the industry in question is a companytrolled industry in other words the specification must be made by the Central Government by reference to, and for the purpose of, the provisions of the Act in order that the Central Government may itself become the appropriate Government qua such industry under s, 2 a i of the Act. It is companyceded by Mr. Sastri that numbersuch specification has been made by the Central Government.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Inclusion in IDRA 1951 First Schedule makes industry controlled under IDRA but s.2(a)(i) IDA requires separate specific specification by Central Government referencing IDA for Central Government to be appropriate government; conceded no such specification exists
